body:
Backgroud:
I compile & install both Python[2.7.8] and Neovim in $HOME/INSTALL. And I have also added $HOME/INSTALL/bin to $PATH.

When start nvim,  below 'COMMENT OUT' check will fail.

```
...
"      \ && index(s:supported, system('python'.s:get_version)) >= 0   --> COMMENT OUT
...
let s:import_result = system(s:python_interpreter_path .
      \ ' -c "import neovim, sys; sys.stdout.write(\"ok\")"')
if s:import_result != 'ok'
"  call s:ShowError('No neovim module found for ' . s:python_version)  --> COMMENT OUT
"  finish  --> COMMENT OUT
...
```

After 'COMMENT OUT' this, my nvim work well with YCM.

```
:echo has('python')
```

return 1

Could anyone give me some comments about this ? Thanks in advance.

comment_data.body:
What's the output of:

```
:echo system('python -c "import neovim, sys; sys.stdout.write(\"ok\")"')
```

The output is:

```
Unmatched ".
```

In the terminal:

```
=> python
Python 2.7.8 (default, Nov 13 2014, 03:54:36) 
[GCC 4.4.7 20120313 (Red Hat 4.4.7-3)] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import neovim, sys;
>>> sys.stdout.write("ok")
ok>>> 
```

> Unmatched ".

Can't reproduce in latest master, nor an earlier build. 

What is the full output of `:version`?

I compile Neovim this morning.

```
NVIM 0.0.0-alpha+201411121623 (compiled Nov 13 2014 04:34:20)
Commit: c5d7d75bb10a3d41bd2c502b010f2148c5e7b796
Build type: Debug
Compilation: /usr/bin/cc -g -Wall -Wextra -pedantic -Wno-unused-parameter -Wstrict-prototypes -std=gnu99 -DINCLUDE_GENERATED_DECLARATIONS -DHAVE_CONFIG_H -I/home/sun/neovim/build/config -I/home/sun/neovim/src -I/home/sun/neovim/.deps/usr/include -I/home/sun/neovim/.deps/usr/include -I/home/sun/neovim/.deps/usr/include/luajit-2.0 -I/usr/include -I/home/sun/neovim/build/src/nvim/auto -I/home/sun/neovim/build/include
Compiled by sun@sun
  Features included (+) or not (-):
+acl             +farsi           -mouse_gpm       -tag_any_white
+arabic          +file_in_path    +mouse_netterm   +terminfo
+autocmd         +find_in_path    +mouse_sgr       +termresponvsusunse
-browse          +float           -mouse_sysmouse  +textobjects
+byte_offset     +folding         +mouse_urxvt     +title
+cindent         -footer          +mouse_xterm     -toolbar
-clipboard       +fork()          +multi_byte      +user_commands
+cmdline_compl   +gettext         +multi_lang      +vertsplit
+cmdline_hist    +iconv           +path_extra      +virtualedit
+cmdline_info    +insert_expand   +persistent_undo +visual
+comments        +jumplist        +postscript      +visualextra
+conceal         +keymap          +printer         +viminfo
+cscope          +langmap         +profile         +vreplace
+cursorbind      +libcall         +quickfix        +wildignore
+cursorshape     +linebreak       +reltime         +wildmenu
+dialog_con      +lispindent      +rightleft       +windows
+diff            +listcmds        +scrollbind      +writebackup
+digraphs        +localmap        +signs           -X11
-dnd             +menu            +smartindent     -xfontset
-ebcdic          +mksession       +startuptime     -xsmp
-emacs_tags      +modify_fname    +statusline      -xterm_clipboard
+eval            +mouse           +syntax          
+ex_extra        -mouseshape      +tag_binary      
+extra_search    +mouse_dec       +tag_old_static  
   system vimrc file: "$VIM/nvimrc"
     user vimrc file: "$HOME/.nvimrc"
 2nd user vimrc file: "~/.nvim/nvimrc"
      user exrc file: "$HOME/.exrc"
  fall-back for $VIM: "/home/sun/INSTALL/share/nvim"
```

lsb_release -a

```
lsb_release -a
LSB Version:    :base-4.0-amd64:base-4.0-noarch:core-4.0-amd64:core-4.0-noarch:graphics-4.0-amd64:graphics-4.0-noarch:printing-4.0-amd64:printing-4.0-noarch
Distributor ID: RedHatEnterpriseServer
Description:    Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server release 6.4 (Santiago)
Release:    6.4
Codename:   Santiago
```

Seems related to shell escaping, I'm out of ideas, but could you share the output of this command:

```
set shell? shellcmdflag? shellpipe? shellquote? shellredir? shelltemp? shellxquote? shellxescape?
```

The output is:

```
  shell=/bin/tcsh
  shellcmdflag=-c
  shellpipe=|& tee
  shellquote=
  shellredir=>&
  shelltemp
  shellxquote=
  shellxescape=
```

One last thing to try (this should work with both vim and nvim, exactly as written below):

```
nvim -u NONE -N -c 'runtime! python_setup.vim' -c "echo system('python -c ''import neovim, sys; sys.stdout.write(\"ok\")''')"
```

You should see "ok" in the statusline.
What if you start nvim from a `bash` shell instead of `tcsh`?

Actually I just tried in tcsh and I get the same issue (in vim 7.4.52 and nvim).

This is where automated builds really shine. Hopefully we can iron this out, write some tests, and make these kinds of dumb problems go away forever. Yes I said forever.

Aha :+1: 
One more question:

```
chsh -s /bin/bash
chsh: can only change local entries; use ypchsh instead.
```

How do you change SHELL ?

`:set shell=/bin/bash`. But you may need to also set the other `shell*` settings (listed above) appropriately. The full carnage of considerations is documented here:

https://github.com/airblade/vim-system-escape

If you didn't mean to set shell, some plugin might be doing it. To see which one, run `:verbose set shell?`.

After set shell to `bash`

```
:set shell=/bin/bash
```

```
:echo system('python -c "import neovim, sys; sys.stdout.write(\"ok\")"')
```

return ok

But when re-open nvim ,  `:verbose set shell?` still `shell=/bin/tcsh`

Ok, seems like you are new to Vim? `:verbose set shell?` should say which file last changed the setting, e.g.:

```
Last set from ~/.nvimrc
```

Also, to make your setting permanent, simply add the line

```
set shell=/bin/bash
```

to your `~/.nvimrc`.

Yeah, I'm freshman. Nvim works well now. Thanks for your great help : )
Does this bug should belong https://github.com/neovim/python-client ?
No, bug belongs here. :beetle:  Thanks for reporting!

@aktau It looks like this is being caused by new `system()` implementation not honoring some of the flags that modify the generated command. There was a little bit of discussion about this [here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/1358#issuecomment-61827112) (see from "I have in fact some reservations").

> @aktau It looks like this is being caused by new system() implementation not honoring some of the flags that modify the generated command. There was a little bit of discussion about this here (see from "I have in fact some reservations").

Yep! Since the new `system` implementation is quite a bit simpler, I propose that this could even be an entry-level issue (at least for someone a bit experienced with different shells).

To me, entry-level tasks should need no previous knowledge of vim's code.
This needs understanding how it was before, how it is now, and in addition, it touches a very critical functionality. Not for newly-arrived, IMO.

> To me, entry-level tasks should need no previous knowledge of vim's code.

We have a difference of thinking there, to me, entry-level means something that doesn't have wide-ranging architectural implications or involves a boatload of code. Since I see this as a quite local change that shouldn't be a diff of more than 30 lines, I thought it was appropriate. Your definition makes sense though.

I do agree that the solution may be short in code.
But you have to previously understand what the problem is, and where you want to go. And that's the difficult part here, IMO.

If we provide a deep explanation of previous situation, and a detailed explanation of what we want the result to be, then this can be handed over. But if you do that, you have 90% of the task done.

In fact, it's maybe in order some discussion regarding what we want the result to be, in order not to repeat previous complexity. We also need some knowledge about other shells to understand this completely.

So, I would start by carefully analyzing previous behaviour, seeing which methods set which flags/options and why that is needed.
Then, we could decide if all of it is needed in new version, and how it could be restructured.

Agree?

Sure!

On Thu, Nov 13, 2014 at 11:37 AM, Eliseo Martínez notifications@github.com
wrote:

> I do agree that the solution may be short in code.
> But you have to previously understand what the problem is, and where you
> want to go. And that's the difficult part here, IMO.
> 
> If we provide a deep explanation of previous situation, and a detailed
> explanation of what we want the result to be, then this can be handed over.
> But if you do that, you have 90% of the task done.
> 
> In fact, it's maybe in order some discussion regarding what we want the
> result to be, in order not to repeat previous complexity. We also need some
> knowledge about other shells to understand this completely.
> 
> So, I would start by carefully analyzing previous behaviour, seeing which
> methods set which flags/options and why that is needed.
> Then, we could decide if all of it is needed in new version, and how it
> could be restructured.
> 
> Agree?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/1465#issuecomment-62871779.

>  It looks like this is being caused by new system()

@aktau  @elmart Not anything new. I reproduced it in Vim 7.4.52 (see [one-liner to reproduce](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/1465#issuecomment-62844949)). You must start Vim/Nvim from within tcsh.

Great. That lessens the urgence of dealing with this.
But I still think that, at some point, we should still do that analysis of previous/current behaviour, cause we know for sure we are not doing some things that were previously done, and are not fully aware of all implications.

milestone.description: Low priority items. We plan to work on this but don't have a target date.
milestone.title: backlog

title: tcsh shell escaping
